## Why document your code?

Reproducibility

FAIR data principles: findable, accessible, interopable, reusable

## Ten simple rules

Lee BD (2018) Ten simple rules for documenting scientific software. PLoS Comput Biol 14(12): e1006561. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006561

1. Write comments as you code
4. Include a README file with basic information
6. Version control your documentation
8. Use automated documentation tools
9. Write error messages that provide solutions or point to your documentation

## What to document

"Document Design and Purpose, Not Mechanics"

Try to write code that is self-documenting.
This means using good, descriptive variable names and adhering to language-specific style guides.

Wilson G, Aruliah DA, Brown CT, Chue Hong NP, Davis M, Guy RT, et al. (2014) Best Practices for Scientific Computing. PLoS Biol 12(1): e1001745. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.1001745
